posts.title: Create your own fully-dockerized blog with Ghost, NGINX and Let's Encrypt
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"Starting from a couple of weeks ago, I have been thinking to create my own blog to share my experiences, thoughts and ingishts about tech – and other stuff. We'll see how it will go!

There are many ready-to-go blogging software (i.e. WordPress, Joomla etc.). However, I was searching for something different — maybe something more modern and elegant.

I came up with [Ghost](https://ghost.org/). Ghost is a publishing platform used by many well-known websites around the world such as Mozilla, DuckDuckGo, Airtable, CodeAcademy, Sky News and many more. What hit me about Ghost in the first place is its design. It is clean, well-organized and easy-to-read.

Ghost has free and paid version. In the paid version — also known as GhostPro — your blog is hosted in Ghost's servers. However, the free version is also available and but you have to host it your own. In this article, I will explain the steps that I followed to create this blog.

This blog is fully dockerized (i.e. created with docker container). There are three docker images used:

1. NGINX 
2. Let's Encrypt
3. Ghost

I used NGINX for [reverse-proxy](https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/cdn/glossary/reverse-proxy/). For those who never heard reverse-proxy, it is quite simple technology which send requests to web servers. Let's say you have multiple service in your machine (e.g. WordPress, Joomla, and Ghost), the reverse-proxy looks at the request and sends the client to the right service.

Let's Encrypt is another initiative sponsored by big companies such as Facebook, Google and Mozilla. They provide free SSL certificates. Instead of paying hundres of bucks for a simple SSL certificate, they give free for you!

For all the docker containers I used docker-compose which is a tool to run multiple docker containers and manage them from a single file.

My design is quite simple: I created a folder called nginx. It includes a single file: docker-compose.yml

```
version: '2'

services:
  nginx-proxy:
    restart: always
    image: jwilder/nginx-proxy:alpine
    container_name: nginx-proxy
    ports:
      - "80:80"
      - "443:443"
    volumes:
      - "/etc/nginx/vhost.d"
      - "/usr/share/nginx/html"
      - "certs:/etc/nginx/certs:ro"
      - "/var/run/docker.sock:/tmp/docker.sock:ro"
  nginx-letsencrypt:
    restart: always
    image: jrcs/letsencrypt-nginx-proxy-companion
    container_name: nginx-letsencrypt
    depends_on:
      - nginx-proxy
    volumes_from:
      - nginx-proxy
    volumes:
      - '/usr/docker/nginx/conf.d:/etc/nginx/conf.d/:rw'
      - '/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock:ro'
      - "certs:/etc/nginx/certs:rw"
networks:
  default:
    external:
      name: proxy
```

and then run
```
docker-compose up
```

I created another folder called ghost and put a docker-compose file.

```
version: '2'

services:
  ghost:
    image: ghost:1-alpine
    restart: always
    ports:
      - 8080:2368
    depends_on:
      - db
    volumes:
      - './persist/ghost:/var/lib/ghost/content'
    environment:
      VIRTUAL_HOST: [HOSTNAME]
      LETSENCRYPT_HOST: [HOSTNAME]
      LETSENCRYPT_EMAIL: [EMAIL]
      url: https://blog.mert.im
      database__client: mysql
      database__connection__host: db
      database__connection__user: root
      database__connection__password: [PASSWORD]
      database__connection__database: blogdb
  db:
    image: mysql:5.7
    restart: always
    volumes:
      - './persist/mysql:/var/lib/mysql'
    environment:
      MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD: [PASSWORD]
networks:
    default:
        external:
            name: proxy
```

In the same folder, create also a folder to persist your container's data (i.e. blog settings, articles etc.). I called it persist. Persist folder includes another two folder: ghost and mysql. The first one persists the Ghost-related settings and the latter one keeps all the MySQL data.

and like before, run the containers:

```
docker-compose up
```

"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
Starting from a couple of weeks ago, I have been thinking to create my own blog to share my experiences, thoughts and ingishts about tech – and other stuff. We'll see how it will go!

There are many ready-to-go blogging software (i.e. WordPress, Joomla etc.). However, I was searching for something different — maybe something more modern and elegant.

I came up with Ghost. Ghost is a publishing platform used by many well-known websites around the world such as Mozilla, DuckDuckGo, Airtable, CodeAcademy, Sky News and many more. What hit me about Ghost in the first place is its design. It is clean, well-organized and easy-to-read.

Ghost has free and paid version. In the paid version — also known as GhostPro — your blog is hosted in Ghost's servers. However, the free version is also available and but you have to host it your own. In this article, I will explain the steps that I followed to create this blog.

This blog is fully dockerized (i.e. created with docker container). There are three docker images used:

  1. NGINX
  2. Let's Encrypt
  3. Ghost

I used NGINX for reverse-proxy. For those who never heard reverse-proxy, it is quite simple technology which send requests to web servers. Let's say you have multiple service in your machine (e.g. WordPress, Joomla, and Ghost), the reverse-proxy looks at the request and sends the client to the right service.

Let's Encrypt is another initiative sponsored by big companies such as Facebook, Google and Mozilla. They provide free SSL certificates. Instead of paying hundres of bucks for a simple SSL certificate, they give free for you!

For all the docker containers I used docker-compose which is a tool to run multiple docker containers and manage them from a single file.

My design is quite simple: I created a folder called nginx. It includes a single file: docker-compose.yml

version: '2'

services:
  nginx-proxy:
    restart: always
    image: jwilder/nginx-proxy:alpine
    container_name: nginx-proxy
    ports:
      - "80:80"
      - "443:443"
    volumes:
      - "/etc/nginx/vhost.d"
      - "/usr/share/nginx/html"
      - "certs:/etc/nginx/certs:ro"
      - "/var/run/docker.sock:/tmp/docker.sock:ro"
  nginx-letsencrypt:
    restart: always
    image: jrcs/letsencrypt-nginx-proxy-companion
    container_name: nginx-letsencrypt
    depends_on:
      - nginx-proxy
    volumes_from:
      - nginx-proxy
    volumes:
      - '/usr/docker/nginx/conf.d:/etc/nginx/conf.d/:rw'
      - '/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock:ro'
      - "certs:/etc/nginx/certs:rw"
networks:
  default:
    external:
      name: proxy

and then run

docker-compose up

I created another folder called ghost and put a docker-compose file.

version: '2'

services:
  ghost:
    image: ghost:1-alpine
    restart: always
    ports:
      - 8080:2368
    depends_on:
      - db
    volumes:
      - './persist/ghost:/var/lib/ghost/content'
    environment:
      VIRTUAL_HOST: [HOSTNAME]
      LETSENCRYPT_HOST: [HOSTNAME]
      LETSENCRYPT_EMAIL: [EMAIL]
      url: https://blog.mert.im
      database__client: mysql
      database__connection__host: db
      database__connection__user: root
      database__connection__password: [PASSWORD]
      database__connection__database: blogdb
  db:
    image: mysql:5.7
    restart: always
    volumes:
      - './persist/mysql:/var/lib/mysql'
    environment:
      MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD: [PASSWORD]
networks:
    default:
        external:
            name: proxy

In the same folder, create also a folder to persist your container's data (i.e. blog settings, articles etc.). I called it persist. Persist folder includes another two folder: ghost and mysql. The first one persists the Ghost-related settings and the latter one keeps all the MySQL data.

and like before, run the containers:

docker-compose up
posts.plaintext:
Starting from a couple of weeks ago, I have been thinking to create my own blog
to share my experiences, thoughts and ingishts about tech – and other stuff.
We'll see how it will go!

There are many ready-to-go blogging software (i.e. WordPress, Joomla etc.).
However, I was searching for something different — maybe something more modern
and elegant.

I came up with Ghost [https://ghost.org/]. Ghost is a publishing platform used
by many well-known websites around the world such as Mozilla, DuckDuckGo,
Airtable, CodeAcademy, Sky News and many more. What hit me about Ghost in the
first place is its design. It is clean, well-organized and easy-to-read.

Ghost has free and paid version. In the paid version — also known as GhostPro —
your blog is hosted in Ghost's servers. However, the free version is also
available and but you have to host it your own. In this article, I will explain
the steps that I followed to create this blog.

This blog is fully dockerized (i.e. created with docker container). There are
three docker images used:

 1. NGINX
 2. Let's Encrypt
 3. Ghost

I used NGINX for reverse-proxy
[https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/cdn/glossary/reverse-proxy/]. For those who
never heard reverse-proxy, it is quite simple technology which send requests to
web servers. Let's say you have multiple service in your machine (e.g.
WordPress, Joomla, and Ghost), the reverse-proxy looks at the request and sends
the client to the right service.

Let's Encrypt is another initiative sponsored by big companies such as Facebook,
Google and Mozilla. They provide free SSL certificates. Instead of paying
hundres of bucks for a simple SSL certificate, they give free for you!

For all the docker containers I used docker-compose which is a tool to run
multiple docker containers and manage them from a single file.

My design is quite simple: I created a folder called nginx. It includes a single
file: docker-compose.yml

version: '2'

services:
  nginx-proxy:
    restart: always
    image: jwilder/nginx-proxy:alpine
    container_name: nginx-proxy
    ports:
      - "80:80"
      - "443:443"
    volumes:
      - "/etc/nginx/vhost.d"
      - "/usr/share/nginx/html"
      - "certs:/etc/nginx/certs:ro"
      - "/var/run/docker.sock:/tmp/docker.sock:ro"
  nginx-letsencrypt:
    restart: always
    image: jrcs/letsencrypt-nginx-proxy-companion
    container_name: nginx-letsencrypt
    depends_on:
      - nginx-proxy
    volumes_from:
      - nginx-proxy
    volumes:
      - '/usr/docker/nginx/conf.d:/etc/nginx/conf.d/:rw'
      - '/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock:ro'
      - "certs:/etc/nginx/certs:rw"
networks:
  default:
    external:
      name: proxy


and then run

docker-compose up


I created another folder called ghost and put a docker-compose file.

version: '2'

services:
  ghost:
    image: ghost:1-alpine
    restart: always
    ports:
      - 8080:2368
    depends_on:
      - db
    volumes:
      - './persist/ghost:/var/lib/ghost/content'
    environment:
      VIRTUAL_HOST: [HOSTNAME]
      LETSENCRYPT_HOST: [HOSTNAME]
      LETSENCRYPT_EMAIL: [EMAIL]
      url: https://blog.mert.im
      database__client: mysql
      database__connection__host: db
      database__connection__user: root
      database__connection__password: [PASSWORD]
      database__connection__database: blogdb
  db:
    image: mysql:5.7
    restart: always
    volumes:
      - './persist/mysql:/var/lib/mysql'
    environment:
      MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD: [PASSWORD]
networks:
    default:
        external:
            name: proxy


In the same folder, create also a folder to persist your container's data (i.e.
blog settings, articles etc.). I called it persist. Persist folder includes
another two folder: ghost and mysql. The first one persists the Ghost-related
settings and the latter one keeps all the MySQL data.

and like before, run the containers:

docker-compose up

posts.title: Oil Dilution problem in Honda's 1.5 liter engines
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"A couple of months ago I received a letter from Honda Canada. It was talking about a crucial problem in Honda's 1.5 liter Earth Dream engines — a problem affecting millions of cars worldwide.

Japan's Honda is known for producing reliable and dependable cars for many years. Part of the reputation comes from their reliable and efficent engines. Their signature VTEC engines are loved by many car enthatustics for decades. A well-maintained Honda would easily do 300+ miles. Besides, I have seen videos of Honda cars over 1 million kms. Yes 1 million!

Back in 2018, I bought a 1.5 liter turbo-charged Honda Civic and one of the reasons why I bought it was obviously the company's reputation for reliability. The car is great although it has small issues like it has no volume knob — which they fixed in 2019 models — and [bluetooth issues](https://www.10thcivicforum.com/forum/9-10th-gen-civic-general-discussion-forum/19386-bluetooth-issues.html). Overall, I never had a real problem so far.

The letter I got from Honda Canada was talking about oil dilution problem in 1.5 liter engines (a.k.a. Earth Dream engines) which is used by Civics, CRVs and Accords. I was like what? What is oil dilution? 

Oil dilution happens when certain amount of fuel pass down between the pistions and cyclinder walls and dilute the engine oil. The diluted oil can cause the oil chemically degrade and makes it less effective to lubricate the engine. This cause engine and the parts to worn faster — a lot faster.

[![Understanding Oil Dilution ](https://img.youtube.com/vi/0jonzqLK6Io/0.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0jonzqLK6Io)

Oil diluton happens especially in cold weathers like Canada. The engine doesn't warm up enough to burn the excessive fuel in the oil tank. The situation becomes worst especially in short rides since the engine never has time to be warm enough to burn the fuel. 

So what is the fix? The fix involves transmission and engine software changes to make engine to warm up quicker. Ignition timing, CVT control and climate control systems are updated to help the engine warm up and burn the fuel in the oil tank.

I got my car fixed, but I am still not sure if the proposed fix is working well. When I check my oil stick, I DON'T have the excessive oil BUT when I open A/C, I smell fuel inside of cabin. This is one of the complaints about Honda cars and people relate this issue to the oil dilution problem.

So my suggestion is that if you are going to buy a Honda car, rethink. If you insist that you will buy a Civic, go with the 2.0 liter engine — which is also suggested by Consumer Reports — not the 1.5 liter.



"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
A couple of months ago I received a letter from Honda Canada. It was talking about a crucial problem in Honda's 1.5 liter Earth Dream engines — a problem affecting millions of cars worldwide.

Japan's Honda is known for producing reliable and dependable cars for many years. Part of the reputation comes from their reliable and efficent engines. Their signature VTEC engines are loved by many car enthatustics for decades. A well-maintained Honda would easily do 300+ miles. Besides, I have seen videos of Honda cars over 1 million kms. Yes 1 million!

Back in 2018, I bought a 1.5 liter turbo-charged Honda Civic and one of the reasons why I bought it was obviously the company's reputation for reliability. The car is great although it has small issues like it has no volume knob — which they fixed in 2019 models — and bluetooth issues. Overall, I never had a real problem so far.

The letter I got from Honda Canada was talking about oil dilution problem in 1.5 liter engines (a.k.a. Earth Dream engines) which is used by Civics, CRVs and Accords. I was like what? What is oil dilution?

Oil dilution happens when certain amount of fuel pass down between the pistions and cyclinder walls and dilute the engine oil. The diluted oil can cause the oil chemically degrade and makes it less effective to lubricate the engine. This cause engine and the parts to worn faster — a lot faster.

Oil diluton happens especially in cold weathers like Canada. The engine doesn't warm up enough to burn the excessive fuel in the oil tank. The situation becomes worst especially in short rides since the engine never has time to be warm enough to burn the fuel.

So what is the fix? The fix involves transmission and engine software changes to make engine to warm up quicker. Ignition timing, CVT control and climate control systems are updated to help the engine warm up and burn the fuel in the oil tank.

I got my car fixed, but I am still not sure if the proposed fix is working well. When I check my oil stick, I DON'T have the excessive oil BUT when I open A/C, I smell fuel inside of cabin. This is one of the complaints about Honda cars and people relate this issue to the oil dilution problem.

So my suggestion is that if you are going to buy a Honda car, rethink. If you insist that you will buy a Civic, go with the 2.0 liter engine — which is also suggested by Consumer Reports — not the 1.5 liter.
posts.plaintext:
A couple of months ago I received a letter from Honda Canada. It was talking
about a crucial problem in Honda's 1.5 liter Earth Dream engines — a problem
affecting millions of cars worldwide.

Japan's Honda is known for producing reliable and dependable cars for many
years. Part of the reputation comes from their reliable and efficent engines.
Their signature VTEC engines are loved by many car enthatustics for decades. A
well-maintained Honda would easily do 300+ miles. Besides, I have seen videos of
Honda cars over 1 million kms. Yes 1 million!

Back in 2018, I bought a 1.5 liter turbo-charged Honda Civic and one of the
reasons why I bought it was obviously the company's reputation for reliability.
The car is great although it has small issues like it has no volume knob — which
they fixed in 2019 models — and bluetooth issues
[https://www.10thcivicforum.com/forum/9-10th-gen-civic-general-discussion-forum/19386-bluetooth-issues.html]
. Overall, I never had a real problem so far.

The letter I got from Honda Canada was talking about oil dilution problem in 1.5
liter engines (a.k.a. Earth Dream engines) which is used by Civics, CRVs and
Accords. I was like what? What is oil dilution?

Oil dilution happens when certain amount of fuel pass down between the pistions
and cyclinder walls and dilute the engine oil. The diluted oil can cause the oil
chemically degrade and makes it less effective to lubricate the engine. This
cause engine and the parts to worn faster — a lot faster.

  [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0jonzqLK6Io]

Oil diluton happens especially in cold weathers like Canada. The engine doesn't
warm up enough to burn the excessive fuel in the oil tank. The situation becomes
worst especially in short rides since the engine never has time to be warm
enough to burn the fuel.

So what is the fix? The fix involves transmission and engine software changes to
make engine to warm up quicker. Ignition timing, CVT control and climate control
systems are updated to help the engine warm up and burn the fuel in the oil
tank.

I got my car fixed, but I am still not sure if the proposed fix is working well.
When I check my oil stick, I DON'T have the excessive oil BUT when I open A/C, I
smell fuel inside of cabin. This is one of the complaints about Honda cars and
people relate this issue to the oil dilution problem.

So my suggestion is that if you are going to buy a Honda car, rethink. If you
insist that you will buy a Civic, go with the 2.0 liter engine — which is also
suggested by Consumer Reports — not the 1.5 liter.
